subject: Support for haptics motor
description_text:
Hi Team,

I bought a couple of haptics motors, and when I test them they have
a different sound, where one is very loud compared to the other, please see
the attached video.

The sound matches if I turn the loud motor upside down.

Any ideas?

Thank you,
mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579

conversations.body_text: Hi Michele Salcuni,  Please provide your order number and a photo of the motor installed on the pedals so that we can verify the issue.

The Order #SSN2259,

About the picture you're asking for, I sent a video and the noise is there
even without having the haptic mounted, this clarify that the noise is not
related to the way how it has been mounted on the pedal.

Please let me know if you need anything else from me.

Best regards,
mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579

Hi Michele Salcuni,   Does using the 30Hz vibration frequency affect your experience? The inconsistency in sound may be caused by slight differences in washer sizes during assembly, and we are working on improvements. Please mainly check whether the vibration effect meets your expectations.

I tried many frequencies, and basically I feel the internal motor to hit
the metal all the time during the use of it.
This is covering the effect of the other motor that, so far is working fine.

Anyway in the vertical position the metal hit is always there, it stops if
I put is upsidedown.

How can I fix it? Are you going to send me the new washers or I need to
send the haptic back to you?

Thank you for your help.

Best regards,
mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579

Hi Michele Salcuni,  Do you have any M3 hex socket screws available? Please try opening the top cover of the motor—you should see a moving counterweight inside. It is likely that the original M3×10 screws are too long, causing the metallic knocking sound. Replacing them with two M3×8 screws should solve the issue. After opening it, please take a photo and send it to me, and I will point out the exact location for you.

Hi Michele,

I can definitely try replacing the screws myself. Would it be possible for
you to provide a diagram of the haptic motor's internal mechanics?

I believe it would be faster and easier for me to address the issue by
opening it up and checking for the correct screw directly, rather than
exchanging photos and waiting for further instructions.

Regards,
mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579

Hi Michele Salcuni,     You can open the top cover and gently take the motor out without worrying about causing any damage. On the part indicated by the arrow, there is a stainless steel counterweight fixed in place, but the screws are too long, which may cause internal collisions.

Hi [Recipient Name],

Thank you for the information. I see three arrows pointing to five holes.
Could you please confirm if I need to check whether the screw heads are
flush with the motor surface?

Best regards,
Michele

mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579

Hi Michele Salcuni,   Since it’s nighttime, I don’t have suitable photos at the moment. Please ignore the middle arrow; the issue is with the screws on both sides—their locking direction is hitting another part of the voice coil motor because the screws are too long.

Hi [Recipient Name],

Thanks for the information. I'll proceed with opening the motor and
checking the screws as you suggested. I estimate it will take me about 15
minutes to do this.

I'll let you know what I find.

Best regards,
mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579

Hi there,
I see the 2 screw signs on the base of the motor I guess I need to remove
and replace them, right?

What kind of grease do you use?

Regards,
mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579
Hi Michele Salcuni,  Great job! Your photos are very clear. The issue is indeed caused by these two screws being too long, which leads to the collision. We are using general-purpose grease.

Hi there,

I've made some progress on the motor issue and wanted to provide an update,
along with attached pictures for reference.

I trimmed 2mm from the screws and confirmed they were no longer protruding
from the thread. I also addressed the damage caused by the longer screws
and reassembled everything. However, the noise persisted.

Upon further inspection, I discovered a third screw that was also causing
contact from the other side. After trimming this screw as well and
reassembling the motor, the noise finally stopped.

I also noticed what appears to be excessive torque used to tighten the top
and bottom of the motor, as there were metal residues that I had to clean
from all the screws before reassembly. Additionally, the rings at the
bottom of the motor seem to have different external dimensions, which I'm
not sure is intentional.

Overall, I had to troubleshoot, fix, and maintain what is essentially a new
motor, which wasn't ideal.

Regards,
Michele



mks
mobile +49 1522 795 4579

Hi Michele Salcuni,    We will provide you with a compensation of 10 USD. Regarding the washer design, there are a total of five pieces: three with a 28mm diameter and 1.0mm wire thickness, and two with a 1.5mm wire thickness. This is why they may appear slightly different.

Hi there,

Thank you for providing the details about the washers. I appreciate the
quality of the materials in your products; perhaps a bit more control
during assembly would be beneficial.

Regarding the issue, I was able to fix the problem and do not require the
$10 voucher you offered, but I appreciate the gesture.

I truly value your support and your company's commitment to producing good
products. I understand the effort involved in your work, and I'm glad we
could resolve this issue amicably.

Thank you again for your help, and best of luck with your new premium pedal
set!

Take care,
mks
